Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Algorithms and Computations for RNA Structure Prediction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project concerns the development of efficient algorithms and programs for RNA structure prediction, using both established models of RNA structure and dynamics, and emerging new models. Computational RNA structure prediction is a classic area of research, starting more than thirty years ago, and yet it is still a vital and open area. The motivation for this project is based on three fairly recent developments. First, in the last decade, there has been a huge growth in understanding of the varied biological roles and properties of RNA. Second, there has been recent, yet still limited, progress on experimentally determining new RNA structures and dynamics. Finally, and most central to this project, there have been recent theoretical and practical advances in the time and space-efficiency of solutions to classic problems of RNA structure prediction. This also points to the fact that additional powerful algorithmic techniques developed in the computer science community have not been fully exploited (or in some cases ever applied) to problems of RNA structure prediction. This provides a clear and compelling opportunity to improve computational RNA structure prediction, i.e., through improvement in the efficiency (in time and space) of computational methods, and by incorporating new biological and structural insights into the formulation of computational models and problems.

This project will improve the efficiency of algorithms for a variety of RNA structure prediction problems through the further development and exploitation of known, powerful algorithmic techniques that have not been previously introduced or fully exploited in addressing RNA structure problems. The project will also provide implementations of these ideas as computer programs and empirically validate the theory. The project will also articulate new computational problems and models for RNA structure and dynamics, driven by new and emerging biological and structural results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the development of time and space-efficient

computer algorithms and programs to predict the two-dimensional

structure of RNA molecules, using both established models of RNA

structure and dynamics, and emerging new models.

 

In the last decades, there has been a huge growth in our awareness

and understanding of the varied biological roles and properties of

RNA, and there has been recent, yet still limited, progress on

experimentally determining new RNA structures and dynamics.  Most

important to this project there had been recent theoretical and

practical advances in the time and space-efficiency of solutions

to classic problems of RNA structure prediction.  We contributed

to those advances, and become aware that additional powerful

algorithmic techniques developed in the computer science community

were not yet fully exploited in problems of RNA structure prediction.

This provided a compelling opportunity to improve computational RNA

structure prediction.

 

What we achieved in this project was a further development of

techniques for efficient prediction of RNA structure and comparison

of RNA structures. For example, we developed the fastest-known

algorithms for RNA structure prediction that allow a more realistic

biological model of RNA structure, i.e., allowing pseudoknots; and

the fastest-known algorithms for comparing two RNA structures. We

also showed how to integrate two best methods for speeding the

computation of RNA structure, and for limiting the amount of computer

memory that is needed.  The result is a computer algorithm to predict

RNA structure that is both as fast as the fastest-known method, and

that uses a little computer memory as the most memory-efficient

algorithm for RNA structure prediction. At the end of the project

we developed new methods based on the use of Integer Linear

Programming, which is now the focus of a new NSF project.  The

project also supported the professional development of one post-doctoral

student, and one graduate student.

 


Last Modified: 01/31/2017
Modified by: Daniel Gusfield
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project focused on the development of time and space-efficient computer algorithms and programs to predict the two-dimensional structure of RNA molecules, using both established models of RNA structure and dynamics, and emerging new models. In the last decades, there has been a huge growth in our awareness and understanding of the varied biological roles and properties of RNA, and there has been recent, yet still limited, progress on experimentally determining new RNA structures and dynamics. Most important to this project there had been recent theoretical and practical advances in the time and space-efficiency of solutions to classic problems of RNA structure prediction. We contributed to those advances, and become aware that additional powerful algorithmic techniques developed in the computer science community were not yet fully exploited in problems of RNA structure prediction. This provided a compelling opportunity to improve computational RNA structure prediction. What we achieved in this project was a further development of techniques for efficient prediction of RNA structure and comparison of RNA structures. For example, we developed the fastest-known algorithms for RNA structure prediction that allow a more realistic biological model of RNA structure, i.e., allowing pseudoknots; and the fastest-known algorithms for comparing two RNA structures. We also showed how to integrate two best methods for speeding the computation of RNA structure, and for limiting the amount of computer memory that is needed. The result is a computer algorithm to predict RNA structure that is both as fast as the fastest-known method, and that uses a little computer memory as the most memory-efficient algorithm for RNA structure prediction. At the end of the project we developed new methods based on the use of Integer Linear Programming, which is now the focus of a new NSF project. The project also supported the professional development of one post-doctoral student, and one graduate student. Last Modified: 01/31/2017 Submitted by: Daniel Gusfield
